repnme.cdata!: Saving lives in high-risk communities in Honduras

abstracts.cdata!:
Through the natural disaster mitigation
            project, Honduras - one of the most vulnerable countries in
            the world - has substantially built disaster risk management
            (DRM) capacity from the local to the central level through
            an innovative and participatory approach. The project
            supported the implementation of DRM programs across 81 of
            the country's most vulnerable municipalities (about a
            third of total municipalities), benefiting approximately
            five million people. At the same time, the project helped to
            improve national capacity for early warning, monitoring, and
            the forecasting of disaster events, particularly floods.

            DISASTER MANAGEMENT IN THE BARRIOS OF TEGUCIGA,TF026865-PHRD-HONDURAS: NATURAL DISASTER MITIGATION,TF025969-PHRD-EMERGENCY DISASTER
            MANAGEMENT AND VULNERABILITY

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Natural Disaster
            Mitigation Project for Honduras were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory; the risk to development outcome was
            moderate; the Bank's performance was satisfactory; and
            the Borrower's performance was also satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: crises provide opportunities to
            promote change, even if the environment for coordination and
            implementation is challenging. Investing in disaster risk
            management pays off in the long term, especially if coupled
            with flexibility and responsiveness to country needs and
            conditions. Small scale Disaster Risk Management (DRM)
            interventions across multiple localities can have a
            substantial country-level impact provided these are
            developed within a strategic framework and adequately
            balanced with capacity building at the central level. DRM
            capacity strengthening at local and community levels
            contributes to ownership and sustainability of results.
            Development of monitoring and evaluation systems and sound
            economic analysis for DRM projects is critical not only to
            measure results but also to draw well-grounded lessons.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Additional Financing for Natural
            Disaster Mitigation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The closing date for Honduras, Natural
            Disaster Mitigation Additional Financing (AF), will be
            extended from September 30, 2010 until December 30, 2010.
            The political change and resulting "pause" meant
            that the project suspended all activities. The amount of
            time requested for the extension is equal to the amount of
            time lost due to the suspension of activities under the
            "pause." This extension will enable Honduras to
            complete the following activities: (a) completion of small
            works to reduce disaster vulnerability at the local level;
            (b) institutionalization of local disaster risk management
            capacity, and (c) completion of procurement of small goods
            and works packages for enhancing emergency response
            capacities for local and national government agencies. The
            credit supporting the Honduras Natural Disaster Mitigation
            Project was approved on May 30, 2000, and became effective
            on February 2, 2001. Following restructuring in 2004 the
            credit's original closing date, April 15, 2005 was
            extended by two years, to April 2, 2007. An extension to
            September 30, 2007 was agreed at the concept stage for the
            AF to ensure continuity until the AF was approved. The AF
            was approved on June 21, 2007 and provided for a three-year
            extension to September 30, 2010.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Additional Financing for Natural
            Disaster Mitigation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to provide an additional credit to
            the Republic of Honduras for the Honduras Natural Disaster
            Mitigation Project. The additional financing will cover
            costs associated with scaled-up, updated and additional
            activities within the Project's development objective
            of improving Honduras' capacity to reduce its
            vulnerability to natural disasters at the municipal level,
            to enhance the impact of what has been a well-performing
            project, specifically by: (a) strengthening the national
            government's institutional capability in disaster
            prevention, mitigation, and response; (b) enhancing
            technical capacity to gather, share, and disseminate
            knowledge concerning natural disasters; and (c) building
            local capacity to assess hazards and vulnerability levels,
            to identify mitigation measures, and to prepare for and
            respond to emergency situations. Some sub-components
            included in the original project which will not be scaled-up
            with the additional financing have been excluded, and some
            other sub-components have been added or updated to reflect
            new Borrower's needs related to disaster risk
            management, including for instance, support to the National
            Territorial Information System (SINIT, Sistema Nacional de
            Infomzacio'n Territorial), which has been developed
            recently, and to the implementation of mitigation measures
            for drought.

repnme.cdata!:
Honduras - Natural Disaster Mitigation
            Project - amendment to the Credit Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This amendment to the Credit Agreement
            of the Natural Disaster Mitigation Project in Honduras
            reflects significant factors that affected project
            implementation and will impact the overall outcome of the
            project. First, it is important that the Borrower's
            national capacity to prevent, mitigate, and respond to
            natural disasters, be institutionalized and strengthened, so
            that local (and national) programs be managed on a permanent
            basis; Second, at appraisal, the Project focused on
            technical assistance, but did not include financing for
            structural or non-structural aspects beyond the preparation
            of engineering designs, and feasibility studies for civil
            works needed for disaster mitigation. As a consequence of
            Hurricane Mitch, normal rains cause regular flooding, and
            landslides, therefore financing for construction, and basic
            infrastructure subprojects should be considered at this
            point of Project implementation. Third, it is necessary to
            improve Project management and coordination, and
            institutionalize project development objectives. The Project
            is seen as a means to promote cross-sectoral collaboration,
            to capitalize upon thematic synergies, and, above all, to
            sustain the development objectives of the Project. In
            particular, the new Office of Disaster Management, will
            develop and institutionalize a National System for
            Attention, Prevention and Mitigation of Natural Disasters
            which would be responsible for coordinating national, and
            local efforts in disaster response and risk management.
            Moreover, an extension of the closing date is required to
            ensure completion of Project implementation, and demonstrate
            continued support to its development objectives, given
            Project activities would not be finished by the current
            closing date, due to a slow implementation during the
            beginning of the project. The Credit Amendment include:
            modifications to required improvements of the national
            capacity of the Borrower, to reduce its vulnerability to
            natural disasters at the municipal level; modifications
            regarding drought management, instead of studies on fluvial
            geomorphology; capacity building for improved drought
            information management, required software, and design and
            implementation of a capacity building plan for drought
            responsiveness; and, support for the creation of a national
            system for disaster risk management, prevention, and
            responsiveness. Modifications to the Credit Agreement are in
            compliance with the Articles of Agreement, and, it is
            recommended to approve the Amendment in accordance with the
            terms set therein.
